Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Dry Preservation of Blood for Long-Term Storage at Ambient Temperatures
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of dried blood for storage at ambient temperatures. Blood transfusions are one of the most common medical procedures in U.S. hospitals and the global market for blood products is over $30 billion. However, red blood cells can only be stored up to six weeks when refrigerated. Red blood cells can be frozen for longer durations using glycerol but the thawing and processing steps are complex and time-consuming. Due to these limitations the blood supply is limited or non-existent in austere environments. Dry preservation of red blood cells at ambient temperatures would enable rapid blood transfusions in austere environments where blood storage is not currently feasible, which would likely save lives in these remote locations. In addition, dried blood is expected to also have an impact on the blood supply for veterinary transfusions. Furthermore, this technology may enable dry preservation of many other cell types for research and medical applications. It is expected that this technology will have a significant impact on human healthcare and will revolutionize civilian and military applications where long-term storage of blood is currently impossible.

This I-Corps project will provide new insights into potential commercialization opportunities for dried blood. A new method has been developed which utilizes ultrasound and microfluidics technology to load red blood cells with trehalose in order to protect the cell membranes when preserved in a dried state. Results from experimental studies have found that this method yields a significant increase in recovery of viable red blood cells compared to other approaches. The activities of this I-Corps project will aid in identifying or excluding potential areas of market fit for dried blood, including military use, veterinary use, blood banking, hospitals/medical centers, and cell preservation for research applications. Customer discovery interviews will provide new insights into the unmet needs and pain points for providers of blood transfusions and other cell preservation applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Blood transfusions have saved millions of lives and are one of the most common medical procedures in the United States. However, blood shortages frequently occur due to the limited storage duration of six weeks when refrigerated. We recently invented a new technology at the University of Louisville to produce dried blood for long-term storage at ambient temperatures. We hypothesized that a dried blood product could address unmet blood supply needs for transfusion medicine. We tested this hypothesis during the I-Corps program by performing over 200 customer discovery interviews with blood bank managers, trauma surgeons, emergency medical personnel, military medics, and others in the field. We learned that the limited shelf-life of blood products and the cold-chain storage requirements have a significant impact on the national and global blood-supply infrastructures. To maintain blood supplies in small towns and remote areas, blood is often collected in major population centers and shipped, sometimes thousands of miles, in cooled containers to areas with lower population density. Shipping and cooling costs can make up a significant portion of the cost of each blood unit, which prohibits some remote clinics from providing blood transfusions. Furthermore, care providers without access to refrigeration, such as medics on the battlefield and clinics in the aftermath of natural disasters, lack the capacity to store blood and administer life-saving transfusions. Based on these interviews we identified and validated that there are significant clinical and market needs for dried blood products, and commercialization of these products would likely have a major impact on saving lives throughout the world.
